sen.j: 川俣事件は、1900年2月13日、群馬県邑楽郡佐貫村川俣（現明和町 (群馬県)）で、足尾鉱毒事件に関して、政府に請願するために出かける途中の農民と警官が衝突した事件。
sen.e: The Kawamata Incident was a struggle that took place on February 13, 1900 in Kawamata, Sanuki Village, Oura-gun, Gunma Prefecture (present-day Meiwa Town, Gunma Prefecture) between police and peasants who were marching to Tokyo to protest to the Meiji government against copper mining poisons caused by the Ashio Mine.

The Kawamata Incident was a struggle that took place on February 13, 1900 in Kawamata, Sanuki Village, Oura County, Gunma Prefecture (the present Meiwa Town, Gunma Prefecture) between police and peasants who were marching to Tokyo to protest to the Meiji government against the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident.
sen.cmt: gun→County, present-day→present, 「足尾鉱毒事件」→the Ashio～ を修正しました。余分なスペースを消しました。
sen.e: The Kawamata Incident was a struggle that took place on February 13, 1900 in Kawamata, Sanuki Village, Oura County, Gunma Prefecture (the present Meiwa Town, Gunma Prefecture) between police and peasants who were marching to Tokyo to protest to the Meiji government against the Ashio Copper Mine Mineral Pollution Incident.

sen.j: 当時は兇徒聚集事件と呼ばれた。
sen.e: At that time this incident was called the Collective Rioting Incident.
At that time this incident was called the Collective Rioting Incident.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを消しました。
sen.e: At that time this incident was called the Collective Rioting Incident.

sen.j: 明治期の大規模な集会・言論弾圧事件として有名。
sen.e: This incident is also known as the Meiji government's severe suppression of a rally and free speech.
This incident is also known as a large scale rally and the event for suppression of speech in the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: Meiji government's～全体を修正しました。
sen.e: This incident is also known as a large scale rally and the event for suppression of speech in the Meiji period.

sen.j: 農民67名が逮捕され、うち51名が兇徒聚集罪などで起訴されたが、1902年12月25日、仙台控訴審で起訴無効という判決が下り、実質的に全員不起訴という形で決着した。
sen.e: Of those 67 peasants arrested in the Kawamata Incident, 51 persons were charged with mass rioting, but on December 25, 1902 the Sendai Court of Appeal finally decided to drop the case and none of them were charged with any crimes.

Of those 67 peasants arrested in the Kawamata Incident, 51 persons were charged with mass rioting, but on December 25, 1902 the Sendai Court of Appeal finally decided to drop the case and none of them were charged with any crimes.

sen.e: Summary

sen.j: 第1回～第3回押出し
sen.e: The First Demonstration - The Third Demonstration
The First Demonstration - The Third Demonstration
The First Demonstration - The Third Demonstration

sen.j: 足尾銅山による鉱毒被害が増大すると、衆議院議員田中正造の主導の下、1896年10月4日、群馬県邑楽郡渡瀬村 (群馬県)（現館林市）にある雲龍寺に、栃木・群馬両県鉱毒事務所がおかれた。
sen.e: As the mine poisoning damages caused by the Ashio copper mine became serious, Shozo TANAKA, a member of the Lower House, set up a mining damage office for both Ibaragi and Gunma Prefecture on October 4, 1896 at Unryu-ji Temple in Watase Village, Oura-gun, Gunma Prefecture (present-day Tatebayashi City, Gunma Prefecture.)

As the mining pollution damage caused by the Ashio copper mine became serious, Shozo TANAKA, a member of the House of Representatives, set up a mining damage office for both Ibaragi and Gunma Prefecture on October 4, 1896 at Unryu-ji Temple in Watase Village, Oura County, Gunma Prefecture (the present Tatebayashi City, Gunma Prefecture.)
sen.cmt: mine poisoning→mining pollution, damages→damage, 「衆議院」→the House of Representatives, gun→County, present-day→the present, を修正しました。
sen.e: As the mining pollution damage caused by the Ashio copper mine became serious, Shozo TANAKA, a member of the House of Representatives, set up a mining damage office for both Ibaragi and Gunma Prefecture on October 4, 1896 at Unryu-ji Temple in Watase Village, Oura County, Gunma Prefecture (the present Tatebayashi City, Gunma Prefecture.)

sen.j: 農民らは結束して東京に請願に出かけることにし、1897年3月2日、第1回の請願が行われた。
sen.e: Peasants gathered and decided to go to Tokyo for the first mass rally on March 2, 1897.
Peasants gathered and decided to go to Tokyo for the first petition on March 2, 1897.
sen.cmt: mass rally→petitionとし、余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: Peasants gathered and decided to go to Tokyo for the first petition on March 2, 1897.

sen.j: 当時、このような活動には名前がなかった。
sen.e: There were no words to describe such a citizens' movement in Japan at that time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: There were no words to describe such a citizens' movement in Japan at that time.
There were no words to describe such a citizens' movement in Japan at that time.

sen.j: そこで農民らは東京大挙押出しと呼んだ。
sen.e: So peasants called it Marching toward Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: So peasants called it "Tokyo Taikyo Oshidashi" (Demonstration in full force in Tokyo).
sen.cmt: 日本名のローマ字表記を加えました。上記の文で「押し出し」をDemonstrationと訳されているので、ここでもそのように修正しました。
sen.e: So peasants called it "Tokyo Taikyo Oshidashi" (Demonstration in full force in Tokyo).

sen.j: 参加者は2000人。
sen.e: The number of demonstrators was 2,000.
The number of demonstrators was 2,000.
The number of demonstrators was 2,000.

sen.j: 農民らは、米を持参して徒歩で数日がかりで東京に向かった。
sen.e: Peasants walked to Tokyo carrying their rice with them and took a few days to get to Tokyo.
Peasants walked to Tokyo carrying their rice with them and took a few days to get to Tokyo.
Peasants walked to Tokyo carrying their rice with them and took a few days to get to Tokyo.

sen.j: 当時、鉄道はあったが、鉱毒被害地から東京までの運賃が、鉱毒で貧困化していた農民らにとっては非常に高かったため、徒歩という方法がとられた。
sen.e: There was a railway to Tokyo, but peasants went to Tokyo on foot, because they were so poor that they could not afford to buy train tickets, due to the mining damages.
There was a railway to Tokyo, but peasants went to Tokyo on foot because they were so poor that they could not afford to buy train tickets due to the mining damages.
There was a railway to Tokyo, but peasants went to Tokyo on foot because they were so poor that they could not afford to buy train tickets due to the mining damages.

sen.j: 第1回押出しは、榎本武揚農商務大臣との面会に成功し、榎本はこの直後、現地視察を行った。
sen.e: In the first demonstration, peasants was able to meet Takeaki ENOMOTO, the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, who right after his meeting with the peasants visited the copper-poisoned area in Ashio.

In the first demonstration, peasants was able to meet Takeaki ENOMOTO, the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, who visited the copper-poisoned area in Ashio right after the meeting with the peasants.
sen.cmt: right after～とvisited～の部分を入れ替えました。his→the としました。
sen.e: In the first demonstration, peasants was able to meet Takeaki ENOMOTO, the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, who visited the copper-poisoned area in Ashio right after the meeting with the peasants.

sen.j: しかし、榎本の視察があまりにおざなりだと感じた農民らは、同1897年3月24日再度押出しを行った。
sen.e: Peasants felt ENMOTO's inspection was not good enough and went to Tokyo again on March 24, 1897.
Peasants felt Enomoto's inspection was not good enough and went to Tokyo again on March 24, 1897.
Peasants felt Enomoto's inspection was not good enough and went to Tokyo again on March 24, 1897.

sen.j: （実際には、榎本は鉱毒被災地の惨状に大変に驚き、第1次鉱毒調査委員会の設置を即決したことが分かっている）規模は7000人と伝えられる。
sen.e: (As a matter of fact, ENOMOTO was very shocked to see the polluted area and instantly decided to set up the first Ashio Copper Mine Survey Committee, which is said to have mobilized 7,000 people for investigation.)

(As a matter of fact, Enomoto was very shocked to see the polluted area and instantly decided to set up the first Ashio Copper Mine Survey Committee.) It is said to have mobilized 7,000 people for investigation.
sen.cmt: ENOMOTO→Enomoto として、括弧の位置を修正しました。
sen.e: (As a matter of fact, Enomoto was very shocked to see the polluted area and instantly decided to set up the first Ashio Copper Mine Survey Committee.) It is said to have mobilized 7,000 people for investigation.

sen.j: 途中の川俣にあった浮き船橋が、警察によって外されており、怒った農民らは対岸まで泳いで渡って船をつないだ。
sen.e: On their way to Tokyo, peasants found that a floating bridge in Kawamata had been removed by the police and in anger they swam to the other side of the river and hitched up boats.
On their way to Tokyo, peasants found that a floating bridge in Kawamata had been removed by the police and in anger they swam to the other side of the river and hitched up boats.
On their way to Tokyo, peasants found that a floating bridge in Kawamata had been removed by the police and in anger they swam to the other side of the river and hitched up boats.

sen.j: （単に農民らの到着が遅かったため、という説もある。当時は夜更けには浮き船橋は通常、外されていた。）
sen.e: (Some people say that the floating bridge had been removed simply because peasants arrived too late.
(Some people say that the floating bridge had been removed simply because peasants arrived too late.
(Some people say that the floating bridge had been removed simply because peasants arrived too late. In those days floating bridges were usually removed by the midnight.)

sen.j: しかし、途中の岩槻市で、警察に芳林寺に押し込められた上に説諭された。
sen.e: In Iwatsuki City peasants were confronted with the police at Horin-ji Temple and the police told them to stop their demonstration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In Iwatsuki City peasants were confronted with the police at Horin-ji Temple and the police told them to stop their demonstration.
In Iwatsuki City peasants were confronted with the police at Horin-ji Temple and the police told them to stop their demonstration.

sen.j: その結果惣代75名を除いて帰郷した。
sen.e: Most peasants except 75 representatives went back home.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Most peasants except 75 representatives went back home.
Most peasants except 75 representatives went back home.

sen.j: 惣代らも、結局3名が農商務省にたどりついただけで、大臣には面会できずに帰った。
sen.e: Only three representatives managed to get to the Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce, but they had no chance to meet the Minister.
Only three representatives managed to get to the Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce, but they had no chance to meet the Minister and went back home.
sen.cmt: went back home を付け足しました。
sen.e: Only three representatives managed to get to the Ministry of Agriculture and Commerce, but they had no chance to meet the Minister and went back home.

sen.j: 鉱毒調査委員会が銅山に設置を命じた鉱毒沈殿池が決壊し、再び鉱毒が下流に流れて被害を及ぼした。
sen.e: Peasants suffered another serious damages from the massive slugs released from the burst of the sedimentation pond built by the Ashio Copper Mine Survey Committee.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Peasants suffered another serious damages from the massive slugs released from the burst of the sedimentation pond built by the Ashio Copper Mine Survey Committee.
Peasants suffered another serious damages from the massive slugs released from the burst of the sedimentation pond built by the Ashio Copper Mine Survey Committee.

sen.j: それが主要な原因となり、第3回の押出しが、1898年9月26日に行われた。
sen.e: Mainly due to this reason peasants started off for Tokyo on September 26, 1898 for the third mass demonstration.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Mainly due to this reason peasants started off for Tokyo on September 26, 1898 for the third mass demonstration.

sen.j: 約10000人が、同様に雲龍寺を起点に東京に向かった。
sen.e: Over 10,000 peasants started for Tokyo from Unryu-ji Temple.
Over 10,000 peasants left for Tokyo from Unryu-ji Temple.
Over 10,000 peasants left for Tokyo from Unryu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 東京府南足立郡渕江村（現東京都足立区）の保木間氷川神社まで、約2500名がたどりついた。
sen.e: Over 2,500 peasants managed to reach Hokima Hikawa-jinja Shrine in Fuchie Village Minami-adachi-gun, Tokyo-fu (present-day Adachi Ward, Tokyo.)
About 2,500 peasants managed to reach Hokima Hikawa-jinja Shrine in Fuchie Village, Minamiadachi County, Tokyo Prefecture (the present Adachi Ward, Tokyo.)

sen.j: ここで、憲兵 (日本軍)隊や警察による説得を受けた。
sen.e: At this place riot police (military forces) and the policed told them to stop demonstration.
At this place, military policemen (Japanese army) and the police told them to stop demonstration.

sen.j: このとき、鉱毒事務所でも重要な役割を担っていた田中正造も説得に当たった。
sen.e: Shozo TANAKA, who had played an important role in establishment of a mining damage office, also advised them not to make a protesting march.
Shozo TANAKA, who had played an important role in establishment of a mining damage office, also persuaded them.
sen.cmt: adviced→persuadedとして、not to make～を除きました。
sen.e: Shozo TANAKA, who had played an important role in establishment of a mining damage office, also persuaded them.

sen.j: 当時、田中は与党議員だったため、自身が農商務大臣に直接かけあうことで収拾がつけられると考えていたとされる。
sen.e: TANAKA, who then was a member of the ruling party, thought he would be able to settle down this problem through discussion with the Minster of Agriculture and Commerce.
Tanaka, who then was a member of the ruling party, thought he would be able to settle down this problem through discussion with the Minster of Agriculture and Commerce.
Tanaka, who then was a member of the ruling party, thought he would be able to settle down this problem through discussion with the Minster of Agriculture and Commerce.

sen.j: 農民らは田中の説得に応じ、惣代50名を残し帰郷した。
sen.e: Peasants accepted TANAKA's advice and went home leaving fifty representatives.
Peasants accepted Tanaka's advice and went home, leaving fifty representatives.
sen.cmt: TANAKA→Tanakaに修正して、コンマを追加しました。

sen.j: 惣代らは、田中の口利きで当時の大石正巳農商務大臣との面会には成功した。
sen.e: The peasant representatives met Masami OISHI, the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce through TANAKA's good offices.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The peasant representatives met Masami OISHI, the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce through Tanaka's good offices.
The peasant representatives met Masami OISHI, the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce through Tanaka's good offices.

sen.j: しかし直後に政権は崩壊、田中も野党議員となった。
sen.e: However, shortly after that the administration collapsed and TANAKA became the opposition lawmaker.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Shortly after that, however, the administration collapsed and Tanaka became the opposition lawmaker.

sen.j: 結局この面会は実を結ばなかった。
sen.e: After all their talks came up dry.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After all their talks came up dry.

The Fourth Demonstration (the Kawamata Incident)
The Fourth Demonstration (the Kawamata Incident)

sen.j: 川俣事件の事実に関しては、後の裁判での証言などがまったくかみ合わない。
sen.e: No consistent testimony was given at the trial of the Kawamata Incident.
No consistent testimony was given at the trial of the Kawamata Incident.
No consistent testimony was given at the trial of the Kawamata Incident.

sen.j: 警官と農民の証言がかみ合わないのは当然だが、農民同士の証言も全くかみあっていない。
sen.e: It is no surprise that there were gaps between the police and peasants in their testimonies, but there were gaps in claims between peasants, too.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is no surprise that there were gaps between the police and peasants in their testimonies, but there were gaps in claims between peasants, too.
It is no surprise that there were gaps between the police and peasants in their testimonies, but there were gaps in claims between peasants, too.

sen.j: そのため事実関係の詳細は不明である。
sen.e: Thus, the details are still unspecified.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Thus, the details are still unspecified.
Thus, the details are still unspecified.

sen.j: 裁判も、起訴無効という形で決着したため、事実関係については決着がついていない。
sen.e: The court eventually decided to drop the case, so the true account of the Kawamata Incident has not been clarified.
The court eventually decided to drop the case, so the true account of the Kawamata Incident has not been clarified.
The court eventually decided to drop the case, so the true account of the Kawamata Incident has not been clarified.

sen.j: 多くの研究者は、農民の証言がより正確だと考えているが、それでも説明のつかない部分が多い。
sen.e: Many researchers think the testimony given by peasants are more exact than those given by the police, but many of peasants' testimony had no proof.
Many researchers think the testimony given by peasants are more exact than those given by the police, but many of peasants' testimony had no proof.
Many researchers think the testimony given by peasants are more exact than those given by the police, but many of peasants' testimony had no proof.

sen.j: 1900年2月、農民らはひそかに会合を開き、次回の押出しの段取りを決めた。
sen.e: In February 1900 the peasants held a secret meeting and discussed the next demonstration.
In February 1900 the peasants held a secret meeting and discussed the next demonstration.
In February 1900 the peasants held a secret meeting and discussed the next demonstration.

sen.j: 前回説得する側に回った田中も、今度は説得することはなく、押出し決行日に合わせて国会で質問することにした。
sen.e: TANAKA, who had previously dissuaded peasants from going for the demonstration, was now agreeable to their plan and decided to put questions to the National Diet session on the day of the demonstration.

Tanaka, who had previously dissuaded peasants from going for the demonstration, was now agreeable to their plan and decided to put questions to the National Diet session on the day of the demonstration.

Tanaka, who had previously dissuaded peasants from going for the demonstration, was now agreeable to their plan and decided to put questions to the National Diet session on the day of the demonstration.

sen.j: 警察に知られるのを防ぐため、決行日は極秘とされた。
sen.e: The date of the demonstration was confidential to prevent the leakage to the police.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The date of the demonstration was confidential to prevent the leakage to the police.
The date of the demonstration was confidential to prevent the leakage to the police.

sen.j: 準備する物だけが農民から農民に口伝で伝えられた。
sen.e: Only the information on the articles necessary for the demonstration was given from mouth to mouth to peasants.

sen.e: Only the information on the articles necessary for the demonstration was given from peasant to peasant by mouth.

sen.j: しかし実際は、集会などに警察が探りをいれており、決行日以外の詳細は警察側も知っていた。
sen.e: However, the information about the plan except the date of the demonstration, was actually passed to the police, who put out feelers in the peasants' assembles.
However, the information about the plan except the date of the demonstration was actually passed to the police, who put out feelers in the peasants' assembles.
However, the information about the plan except the date of the demonstration was actually passed to the police, who put out feelers in the peasants' assembles.

sen.j: 2月12日午後11時ごろ、雲龍寺の鐘が途切れることなく連続して打ち鳴らされた。
sen.e: Around 11:00pm on February, 12 the Unryu-ji Temple's gong was tolled without a pause.
Around 11:00pm on February, 12 the Unryu-ji Temple's gong was tolled without a pause.
Around 11:00pm on February, 12 the Unryu-ji Temple's gong was tolled without a pause.

sen.j: これを合図に、周辺町村の寺も鐘を連続して打ち始めた。
sen.e: At the sound of the gong, surrounding temples started to toll their gongs continuously.
At the sound of the gong, surrounding temples started to toll their gongs continuously.
At the sound of the gong, surrounding temples started to toll their gongs continuously.

sen.j: その音を聞いて、さらに遠方の寺も鐘を打ち始めた。
sen.e: In response to these sounds distant temples also began tolling their gongs.
In response to these sounds distant temples also began tolling their gongs.
In response to these sounds distant temples also began tolling their gongs.

sen.j: この合図は、20里（約80キロメートル）は伝わったという。
sen.e: It is said that the sounds of the temple bells was heard up to about 80 kilometers away.
It is said that the sounds of the temple bells was heard up to about 80 kilometers away.
It is said that the sounds of the temple bells was heard up to about 80 kilometers away.

sen.j: 警官に制止された寺もあったが、隣村の別の寺が鐘を打ち続けるため、制止は無駄であった。
sen.e: Some temples stopped tolling the temples' gongs at the police command, however, it was waste of labor, because the neighboring temples never stopped tolling the gongs.
Some temples stopped tolling the temples' gongs at the police command, however, it was waste of labor, because the neighboring temples never stopped tolling the gongs.
Some temples stopped tolling the temples' gongs at the police command, however, it was waste of labor, because the neighboring temples never stopped tolling the gongs.

sen.j: この合図の仕方は第3回押出しとほぼ同じである。
sen.e: In the event of the previous third demonstration, they gonged to call up demonstrators, too.
How to give a signal was almost the same as the way of the previous third demonstration.
sen.cmt: 文全体を原文に近いものに修正しました。

sen.j: 2月13日午前1時、700から800人の農民が雲龍寺に集結していた。
sen.e: There were about 700 to 800 peasants at Unryu-ji Temple at 1:00am on February 13.
There were about 700 to 800 peasants at Unryu-ji Temple at 1:00am on February 13.
There were about 700 to 800 peasants at Unryu-ji Temple at 1:00am on February 13.

sen.j: 警官は解散を命じたが、農民らは応じなかった。
sen.e: The police ordered to wind up, but the peasants refused.
The police ordered to wind up, but the peasants refused.
The police ordered to wind up, but the peasants refused.

sen.j: 農民らによれば、土足で本堂に上がりこむなど、警官側が乱暴をはたらいたとしている。
sen.e: Peasants said the police were very rude and entered the temple with their shoes on.
Peasants said the police were very rude and entered the temple with their shoes on.
Peasants said the police were very rude and entered the temple with their shoes on.

sen.j: 同日、朝から、雲龍寺に農民が集結した。
sen.e: On that day many peasants came to Unryu-ji Temple from early morning.
On that day many peasants came to Unryu-ji Temple from early morning.
On that day many peasants came to Unryu-ji Temple from early morning.

sen.j: その数は不明であるが、鉱毒事務所の発表では1万2000。
sen.e: The exact number of the demonstrators is unknown, but the Mining Damage Office announced that 12,000 peasants participated in this demonstration.
The exact number of the demonstrators is unknown, but the Mining Damage Office announced that 12,000 peasants participated in this demonstration.
The exact number of the demonstrators is unknown, but the Mining Damage Office announced that 12,000 peasants participated in this demonstration.

sen.j: しかし、このときの人数は警察発表の2500人のほうがより確かだと考える研究者は多い。
sen.e: Many researchers, however, say the correct figure was 2,500 which the police had announced.
Many researchers, however, say the correct figure was 2,500 which the police had announced.
Many researchers, however, say the correct figure was 2,500 which the police had announced.

sen.j: 9時に一行は雲龍寺そばにあった渡良瀬川を渡り、館林市に向かった。
sen.e: At nine o'clock peasants crossed the Watarase River running nearby Unryu-ji Temple and headed toward Tatebayashi City.
At nine o'clock peasants crossed the Watarase-gawa River running nearby Unryu-ji Temple and headed toward Tatebayashi City.
sen.cmt: Watarase River→Watarase-gawa River としました。
sen.e: At nine o'clock peasants crossed the Watarase-gawa River running nearby Unryu-ji Temple and headed toward Tatebayashi City.

sen.j: 群馬県警察部は約50名で監視していたが、一行はこれを突破した。
sen.e: Fifty policemen from Gunma Police were there to watch peasants, but peasants broke through police barriers.
Fifty policemen from Gunma Police were there to watch peasants, but peasants broke through police barriers.
Fifty policemen from Gunma Police were there to watch peasants, but peasants broke through police barriers.

sen.j: 直後、渡良瀬川右岸の農民らと合流。
sen.e: Right after that, peasants stationed on the right side of the Watarase River joined the procession.
Right after that, peasants stationed on the right side of the Watarase-gawa River joined the procession.
sen.cmt: Watarase River→Watarase-gawa River としました。
sen.e: Right after that, peasants stationed on the right side of the Watarase-gawa River joined the procession.

sen.j: 前述の1万2000という数は、途中で合流した農民を含む数と考える研究者もいる。
sen.e: Some researchers say that the number of 12,000 demonstrators includes those who joined the procession later.
Some researchers say that the number of 12,000 demonstrators includes those who joined the procession later.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: Some researchers say that the number of 12,000 demonstrators includes those who joined the procession later.

sen.j: 館林町入口には10名ほどの警官がいたが一行はこれを突破。
sen.e: When demonstrators came to Tatebayashi Town, they were confronted by ten policemen, but demonstrators broke through them.
When demonstrators came to Tatebayashi Town, they were confronted by ten policemen, but demonstrators broke through them.
When demonstrators came to Tatebayashi Town, they were confronted by ten policemen, but demonstrators broke through them.

sen.j: 途中、11時ごろに館林警察署前で数名が拘引されそうになり、負傷者が出た。
sen.e: Around 11 o'clock the police tried to arrest several demonstrators in in front of Tatabayashi Police Office and some were injured.
Around 11 o'clock the police tried to arrest several demonstrators in front of Tatabayashi Police Office and some were injured.
sen.cmt: in in front→in front に修正しました。
sen.e: Around 11 o'clock the police tried to arrest several demonstrators in front of Tatabayashi Police Office and some were injured.

sen.j: 警察側は、農民のうち1名が馬で警察署に乗り入れたのが原因としている。
sen.e: Police said they tried to arrest demonstrators because one demonstrator tried to break into the police office mounting on a horse.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Police said they tried to arrest demonstrators because one demonstrator tried to break into the police office mounting on a horse.
Police said they tried to arrest demonstrators because one demonstrator tried to break into the police office mounting on a horse.

sen.j: 一方当人は馬ごと拘引されそうになったと証言している。
sen.e: However, the person in question said he was arrested together with his horse.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, the person in question said he was arrested together with his horse.
However, the person in question said he was arrested together with his horse.

sen.j: いずれにしても、ここでどのようなやりとりがあったのか詳細は不明である。
sen.e: Anyhow it is still unknown what actually happened there.
Anyhow it is still unknown what actually happened there.
Anyhow it is still unknown what actually happened there.

sen.j: 裁判終結後の農民の言及には、農民側が先に警察署敷地に石を投げ込んだというものもある。
sen.e: Some peasants said after the judgment that demonstrators first threw stones to the police office.
After the judgment, some peasants said that demonstrators first threw stones to the police office.
sen.cmt: after the judgment の位置を修正しました。
sen.e: After the judgment, some peasants said that demonstrators first threw stones to the police office.

sen.j: 小競り合いのあと、正午すぎに農民らは川俣にある浮き船橋に向かった。
sen.e: After a scrimmage with policemen, demonstrators headed toward a floating bridge in Kawamata after noon.
After a scrimmage with policemen, demonstrators headed toward a floating bridge in Kawamata after noon.
After a scrimmage with policemen, demonstrators headed toward a floating bridge in Kawamata after noon.

sen.j: 当時、利根川にはほとんど橋がかかっておらず、川を渡れる場所は実質的に川俣しかなかった。
sen.e: In those days there were no bridges over the Tone River and the only way to cross the river was to use a floating bridge in Kawamata.
In those days there were no bridges over the Tone-gawa River and the only way to cross the river was to use a floating bridge in Kawamata.
sen.cmt: Tone River→Tone-gawa River に修正しました。
sen.e: In those days there were no bridges over the Tone-gawa River and the only way to cross the river was to use a floating bridge in Kawamata.

sen.j: しかし、邑楽用水から利根川までの間には警官隊が5重の防衛ラインを張って待っていたため、農民らは船を運んでいる者たちを先導にして先を進んだ。
sen.e: There were quintuple defense barriers made by riot police between Oura irrigation canal and the Tone River, so demonstrators avoided that route and followed the route led by boatmen.
There were quintuple defense barriers made by riot police between Oura irrigation canal and the Tone-gawa River, so demonstrators avoided that route and followed the route led by boatmen.
sen.cmt: Tone River→Tone-gawa River に修正しました。
sen.e: There were quintuple defense barriers made by riot police between Oura irrigation canal and the Tone-gawa River, so demonstrators avoided that route and followed the route led by boatmen.

sen.j: 前々回の反省から、この回の押出しでは、橋が外されたときに備えて農民らはあらかじめ船を用意していた。
sen.e: From their bitter experience in the demonstration before last, peasants had made arrangement of boats in case the floating bridge had been removed by the police.
From their bitter experience in the demonstration before last, peasants had made arrangement of boats in case the floating bridge had been removed by the police.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: From their bitter experience in the demonstration before last, peasants had made arrangement of boats in case the floating bridge had been removed by the police.

sen.j: 警官隊は解散命令を発した直後に農民らに殴りかかり、先導の船を運んでいた農民らを相次いで逮捕、拘束した（農民らの証言による）。
sen.e: (According to some peasants) the police made a raid upon peasants right after they gave a winding-up order and arrested demonstrators who were carrying the headmost boat.
(According to some peasants) the police made a raid upon peasants right after they gave a winding-up order and arrested demonstrators who were carrying the headmost boat.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: (According to some peasants) the police made a raid upon peasants right after they gave a winding-up order and arrested demonstrators who were carrying the headmost boat.

sen.j: ただし、先頭の船を運んでいた被告農民の中には、停止命令は聞こえなかったと裁判で主張した者もいる。
sen.e: Some of the accused demonstrators who were carrying the boat claimed in court that they heard no winding-up orders.
Some of the accused demonstrators who were carrying the boat claimed in court that they heard no winding-up orders.
Some of the accused demonstrators who were carrying the boat claimed in court that they heard no winding-up orders.

sen.j: 農民らは川俣にある真如寺に連行され、ここで手当てを受けた。
sen.e: Injured demonstrators were taken to Shinnyo-ji Temple and received medical treatment.
Injured demonstrators were taken to Shinnyo-ji Temple and received medical treatment.
Injured demonstrators were taken to Shinnyo-ji Temple and received medical treatment.

sen.j: 川俣の農民は大多数が農民に同情的であり、ほかにも手当て、看護をした者は多くいたという。
sen.e: Many of the peasants in Kawamata had compassion for the demonstrators and took care of them.
Many of the peasants in Kawamata had compassion for the demonstrators and took care of them.
Many of the peasants in Kawamata had compassion for the demonstrators and took care of them.

sen.j: この日逮捕された農民は約50名。
sen.e: On this day fifty demonstrators were arrested.
On this day fifty demonstrators were arrested.
On this day fifty demonstrators were arrested.

sen.j: 警察が首謀者、リーダーと目していた人物らは、14、15日に相次いで逮捕され、逮捕者の数は67名となった。
sen.e: The police arrested the persons whom they regarded as ringleaders on February 14 and 15 and totally sixty-seven demonstrators were arrested.
The police arrested the persons whom they regarded as ringleaders on February 14 and 15 and totally sixty-seven demonstrators were arrested.
The police arrested the persons whom they regarded as ringleaders on February 14 and 15 and totally sixty-seven demonstrators were arrested.

sen.j: この時点で農民は総崩れとなり、散り散りになった。
sen.e: The peasant movement was put to rout at this point.
The peasant movement was put to rout and broken up at this point.
sen.cmt: 「散り散りに」→and broken up を加えました。
sen.e: The peasant movement was put to rout and broken up at this point.

sen.j: ルートは不明だが、東京までたどり着いたものも数十名から数百名はいたとみられるが、その後の請願は行われなかった。
sen.e: Several dozens or several hundreds of peasants managed to get to Tokyo, which it is still unknown how they got there, however, they made no petition to the government.
Several dozens or several hundreds of peasants managed to get to Tokyo, which route is still unknown, however, they made no petition to the government.
sen.cmt: which it is～→which route～としました。余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: Several dozens or several hundreds of peasants managed to get to Tokyo, which route is still unknown, however, they made no petition to the government.

sen.j: 一方、田中正造は事実を知らず、国会で鉱毒問題に関する質問を行っていた。
sen.e: Shozo TANAKA, however, was not informed what was going on in Kawamata when he was raising questions about the copper-mine poisoning at the National Diet session.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Shozo TANAKA, however, was not informed what was going on in Kawamata when he was raising questions about the copper-mine poisoning at the National Diet session.
Shozo TANAKA, however, was not informed what was going on in Kawamata when he was raising questions about the copper-mine poisoning at the National Diet session.

sen.j: 質問後、事件を知ると、2日後に再度事件について質問を行った。
sen.e: Two days later after he knew about the Kawamata Incident, he questioned about this incident.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: After he knew about the Kawamata Incident, he questioned about this incident again two days later.
sen.cmt: Two days later の位置を修正しました。
sen.e: After he knew about the Kawamata Incident, he questioned about this incident again two days later.

sen.j: なお、押出し決行日は、田中の国会質問日があえて選ばれたものである。
sen.e: By the way, the date of demonstration was selected to coincide with the day when TANAKA would pose a question about a mining pollution problem at the National Diet session.
By the way, the date of demonstration was selected to coincide with the day when Tanaka would pose a question about a mining pollution problem at the National Diet session.
By the way, the date of demonstration was selected to coincide with the day when Tanaka would pose a question about a mining pollution problem at the National Diet session.

sen.j: 押出しは、第1回から第6回まで武器を持たず、暴力もふるわない形で行われている。
sen.e: No weapons or violence was used at the all six demonstrations.
No weapons or violence was used at the all six demonstrations.
No weapons or violence was used at the all six demonstrations.

sen.j: このため、事件となった第4回押出しも、農民側が先に警官に暴力をふるった例はないと考える研究者が多い。
sen.e: Thus, many researchers think that it was unlikely that peasants first did violence to the police on the fourth demonstration which developed into an incident.
Thus, many researchers think that it was unlikely that peasants first did violence to the police on the fourth demonstration which developed into an incident.
Thus, many researchers think that it was unlikely that peasants first did violence to the police on the fourth demonstration which developed into an incident.

sen.j: 当時現場にいた新聞記者らも、裁判で証人として出廷したが、警官隊がサーベルなどの武器を用いたという証言はない。
sen.e: The newspaper reporters who witnessed the incident testified in court that the police did not use sabers or any other weapons.
The newspaper reporters who witnessed the incident testified in court that the police did not use sabers or any other weapons.
The newspaper reporters who witnessed the incident testified in court that the police did not use sabers or any other weapons.

sen.j: また、農民が武器を使用したという証言もない。
sen.e: No one witnessed demonstrators using any weapons.
No one witnessed demonstrators using any weapons.
No one witnessed demonstrators using any weapons.

sen.j: 警官側が農民に対し砂を投げた、という証言と、警官と農民の両者が砂を投げた、という証言がある。
sen.e: Some said police threw sands at demonstrators and other said police and peasants both threw sands to each other.
Some said police threw sands at demonstrators and other said police and peasants both threw sands to each other.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: Some said police threw sands at demonstrators and other said police and peasants both threw sands to each other.

sen.j: 起訴
sen.e: Prosecution
Prosecution
Prosecution

sen.j: 予審取調べは直後から行われた。
sen.e: Preliminary examination was conducted just after the incident.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Preliminary examination was conducted just after the incident.
Preliminary examination was conducted just after the incident.

sen.j: 7月9日、51名を有罪（起訴相当）、16名が不起訴となった。
sen.e: On July 9, fifty-one persons were accused and sixteen were exempted from prosecution.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: On July 9, fifty-one persons were found guilty (prosecution) and sixteen were exempted from prosecution.
sen.cmt: 有罪（起訴相当）→was found guilty～ としました。
sen.e: On July 9, fifty-one persons were found guilty (prosecution) and sixteen were exempted from prosecution.

sen.j: 不起訴となった者は釈放された。
sen.e: Those who were not accused were released.
Those who were not accused were released.
Those who were not accused were released.

sen.j: 取り調べで特に拷問や自白の強要が行われたという記録はない。
sen.e: There is no record of torture or forced confession during the examination.
There is no record of torture or forced confession during the examination.
There is no record of torture or forced confession during the examination.

sen.j: ただし、調書に、検察側の意図的な聞き誤りが多く含まれるという研究もある。
sen.e: However, some researchers say there were plenty of intentional mishearing by prosecutors in the investigation papers.
However, some researchers say there were plenty of intentional mishearing by prosecutors in the investigation papers.
However, some researchers say there were plenty of intentional mishearing by prosecutors in the investigation papers.

sen.j: 農民5名が「暴動首魁ノ所為」、雲龍寺住職1名が「暴動教唆ノ所為」、農民17名が「扇動の所為」で、それぞれ重罪、残りの28名は軽罪で起訴された。
sen.e: Five peasants were charged with collective rioting and Unryu-ji Temple's chief priest was charged with masterminding a riot and seventeen peasants were charged with fomenting a riot, and the rest of twenty-eight peasants were charged with a minor offense.

Five peasants were charged with collective rioting and Unryu-ji Temple's chief priest was charged with masterminding a riot and seventeen peasants were charged with fomenting a riot, and the rest of twenty-eight peasants were charged with a minor offense.

Five peasants were charged with collective rioting and Unryu-ji Temple's chief priest was charged with masterminding a riot and seventeen peasants were charged with fomenting a riot, and the rest of twenty-eight peasants were charged with a minor offense.

sen.j: また、一部の農民は、治安警察法でも起訴された。
sen.e: Some of the peasants were charged with violating the Security Police Law.
Some of the peasants were charged with violating the Security Police Law.
Some of the peasants were charged with violating the Security Police Law.

sen.j: なお、治安警察法は、事件の起きた1900年2月13日にはまだ成立していない。
sen.e: By the way, the Security Police Law was not yet enacted when the Kawamata Incident occurred on February 13, 1900.
By the way, the Security Police Law was not yet enacted when the Kawamata Incident occurred on February 13, 1900.
By the way, the Security Police Law was not yet enacted when the Kawamata Incident occurred on February 13, 1900.

sen.j: （旧法よりも、新法である治安警察法のほうが最高刑が軽いため、新法での起訴となったという説もある。
sen.e: (Some researchers say the new law was adopted because the maximum sentence is lighter in a new law than an older law.
(Some researchers say the new law was adopted because the maximum sentence is lighter in a new law than an older law.
(Some researchers say the new law was adopted because the maximum sentence is lighter in a new law than an older law.

sen.j: ただし、罰金は治安警察法のほうが高額になっている）
sen.e: However, the amount of fines was higher in the Security Police Law.)
However, the amount of fines was higher in the Security Police Law.)
However, the amount of fines was higher in the Security Police Law.)

sen.j: 1審の前橋地裁では、60余名の大弁護団が組織された。
sen.e: A large defense team consisted of sixty lawyers was organized at the first trial in Maebashi District Court.
A large defense team consisted of sixty lawyers was organized at the first trial in Maebashi District Court.
A large defense team consisted of sixty lawyers was organized at the first trial in Maebashi District Court.

sen.j: この60名は全員が無償で弁護にあたった。
sen.e: Sixty lawyers were all worked without recompense.
Sixty lawyers were all worked without recompense.
Sixty lawyers were all worked without recompense.

sen.j: ただし、一度も公判に出席しなかった弁護人も10名いる。
sen.e: However, ten lawyers never attended at the public trial.
However, ten lawyers never attended the public trial.
However, ten lawyers never attended the public trial.

sen.j: 10月10日に第1回公判が開かれ、12月22日、判決がおりた。
sen.e: The first public trial was held on October 10 and the sentence was passed on December 22.
The first public trial was held on October 10 and the sentence was passed on December 22.
The first public trial was held on October 10 and the sentence was passed on December 22.

sen.j: 2名が治安警察法で有罪（禁固2ヶ月）、官吏抗拒罪で罰金と禁固（4ヶ月～2年）が27名、無罪21名であった。
sen.e: Two peasants were sentenced to two months in prison for violating the Security Police Law and twenty-seven peasants were sentenced to fines and imprisonment from four months to two years for obstructing officers and twenty-one peasants were found innocent of any crime.

Two peasants were sentenced to two months' imprisonment for violating the Security Police Law and twenty-seven peasants were sentenced to fines and imprisonment from four months to two years for obstructing officers and twenty-one peasants were found innocent of any crime.
sen.cmt: in prison→imprisonment とし、余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: Two peasants were sentenced to two months' imprisonment for violating the Security Police Law and twenty-seven peasants were sentenced to fines and imprisonment from four months to two years for obstructing officers and twenty-one peasants were found innocent of any crime.

sen.j: （被告のうち1名は公判途中で死去）兇徒聚集罪は認められなかったが、当時現場にいなかった、首謀者とされる農民らに重い刑を科すという意味では、検察側の主張に沿った判決となった。
sen.e: None of the peasants were found guilty of mass rioting (one accused person died during the public court,) but it could be said that the sentence was given in line with the prosecution's claim, because the peasants whom the prosecutions regarded as ringleaders were imposed on a heavy penalty, even though they were not at the incident site.

None of the peasants were found guilty of mass rioting (one accused person died during the public court,) but it could be said that the sentence was given in line with the prosecution's claim because the peasants whom the prosecutions regarded as ringleaders were imposed on a heavy penalty, even though they were not at the incident site.
sen.cmt: コンマと余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: None of the peasants were found guilty of mass rioting (one accused person died during the public court,) but it could be said that the sentence was given in line with the prosecution's claim because the peasants whom the prosecutions regarded as ringleaders were imposed on a heavy penalty, even though they were not at the incident site.

sen.j: この判決に対し、検察側は控訴。
sen.e: The prosecutions appealed against a sentence.
The prosecutions appealed against a sentence.
The prosecutions appealed against a sentence.

sen.j: 被告側も、無罪となった者も含め50名全員が控訴した。
sen.e: Fifty defendants including those who were found not guilty appealed against their sentence.
Fifty defendants including those who were found not guilty appealed against their sentence.
Fifty defendants including those who were found not guilty appealed against their sentence.

sen.j: 裁判に先立ち、収監されていた22名は1901年1月20日すぎに東京に移されたが、3月28日までには全員がいったん釈放された。
sen.e: Twenty-two prisoners were all moved to Tokyo on January 20, 1901 and released by March 28 before the court was held.
Twenty-two prisoners were all moved to Tokyo on January 20, 1901 and once released by March 28 before the court was held.
Twenty-two prisoners were all moved to Tokyo on January 20, 1901 and once released by March 28 before the court was held.

sen.j: （のちに再収監された者はいる）
sen.e: (Some prisoners were imprisoned again later.)
(Some prisoners were imprisoned again later.)
(Some prisoners were imprisoned again later.)

sen.j: 東京控訴院での2審は、9月20日に第1回公判が開かれたが、裁判の場所が東京に移ったことで、事件は東京のマスコミに注目されることとなった。
sen.e: The first public trial of the appellate court was held at the Tokyo Court of Appeal on September 20 and through this the Kawamata Incident received a greater attention by Tokyo news papers.
The first public trial of the appellate court was held at the Tokyo Court of Appeal on September 20 and through this the Kawamata Incident received a greater attention from the mass media in Tokyo.
sen.cmt: by Tokyo news papers→from the mass media in Tokyo としました。
sen.e: The first public trial of the appellate court was held at the Tokyo Court of Appeal on September 20 and through this the Kawamata Incident received a greater attention from the mass media in Tokyo.

sen.j: 2審で被告側は、判事らを鉱毒被害地に臨検させることに成功。
sen.e: The defense succeeded in making judges to inspect the mine-poisoned area.
The defense succeeded in making judges to inspect the mine-poisoned area.
The defense succeeded in making judges to inspect the mine-poisoned area.

sen.j: この臨検にはマスコミも同行し、鉱毒被害は東京のマスコミに広く知られるようになった。
sen.e: Newspaper reporters also went to the poisoned area and the copper-mine poisoning problem became widely known among Tokyo newspapers.
The mass media also went to the poisoned area and the copper-mine poisoning problem became widely known among them in Tokyo.
sen.cmt: Newspaper reporters→The mass media, Tokyo newspapers→them in Tokyo としました。
sen.e: The mass media also went to the poisoned area and the copper-mine poisoning problem became widely known among them in Tokyo.

sen.j: 特に、萬朝報、横浜毎日新聞（現在の毎日新聞とは無関係）、読売新聞などは、鉱毒や、田中正造の直訴事件を連日のように伝えた。
sen.e: Particularly Yorozu Choho, Yokohama Mainichi Shimbun (It has nothing to do with present Mainichi Shimbun), Yomiuri Shimbun reported daily on the copper-mining problem and also about Shozo TANAKA's direct appeal to the emperor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Particularly Yorozu Choho, Yokohama Mainichi Shimbun (It is unrelated to the present Mainichi Shimbun), Yomiuri Shimbun reported daily on the copper-mining problem and also about Shozo TANAKA's direct appeal to the emperor.
sen.cmt: 括弧内を修正しました。
sen.e: Particularly Yorozu Choho, Yokohama Mainichi Shimbun (It is unrelated to the present Mainichi Shimbun), Yomiuri Shimbun reported daily on the copper-mining problem and also about Shozo TANAKA's direct appeal to the emperor.

sen.j: おかげで学生らが団体で連日、鉱毒被害地や足尾銅山の見学をするなど、世論は沸騰した。
sen.e: People showed strong interest in this problem and groups of students visited the poisoned area and the Ashio Mine.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: People showed strong interest in this problem and groups of students visited the poisoned area and the Ashio Mine.
People showed strong interest in this problem and groups of students visited the poisoned area and the Ashio Mine.

sen.j: 第5回、第6回押出し
sen.e: The Fifth Demonstration and The Sixth Demonstration
The Fifth Demonstration and The Sixth Demonstration
The Fifth Demonstration and The Sixth Demonstration

sen.j: 判決は1902年3月15日と決まった。
sen.e: It was announced that sentence would be passed on March 15, 1902.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It was announced that sentence would be passed on March 15, 1902.
It was announced that sentence would be passed on March 15, 1902.

sen.j: これに合わせて、2月19日、3月2日に、第5回、第6回の押出しが行われた。
sen.e: Then peasants held the fifth and the sixth demonstrations on February 19 and March 2 respectively.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Then peasants held the fifth and the sixth demonstrations on February 19 and March 2 respectively.
Then peasants held the fifth and the sixth demonstrations on February 19 and March 2 respectively.

sen.j: 第5回押出しは、それまでの雲龍寺ではなく、埼玉県利島村（現北川辺町）の養性寺を起点として行われた。
sen.e: Peasants started for the fifth demonstration not from formerly-used Unryu-ji Temple but from Yosei-ji Temple in Toshima Village, Saitama Prefecture (present-day Kita-kawabe Town.)
sen.cmt: 養性寺の読み方、いろいろ調べてみましたが、わかりませんでした。ここでは「ようせいじ」と読みました。
sen.e: Peasants started for the fifth demonstration not from formerly-used Unryu-ji Temple but from Yosei-ji Temple in Toshima Village, Saitama Prefecture (the present Kitakawabe Town.)
sen.cmt: 括弧内を修正しました。
sen.e: Peasants started for the fifth demonstration not from formerly-used Unryu-ji Temple but from Yosei-ji Temple in Toshima Village, Saitama Prefecture (the present Kitakawabe Town.)

sen.j: 雲龍寺でも農民が1100人程度集結したが、警官の監視が厳しく、実際に東京に向かえたのは養性寺組の700名だけだった。
sen.e: One thousand and one hundred peasants came to Unryu-ji Temple to join the demonstration, but under the strict supervision by the police only seven hundreds peasants who started from Yosei-ji Temple managed to go to Tokyo.
About 1100 peasants came to Unryu-ji Temple to join the demonstration, but under the strict supervision by the police only 700 peasants who started from Yosei-ji Temple managed to go to Tokyo.
About 1100 peasants came to Unryu-ji Temple to join the demonstration, but under the strict supervision by the police only 700 peasants who started from Yosei-ji Temple managed to go to Tokyo.

sen.j: この押出しは、女性が多かったため女押出しとも呼ばれる。
sen.e: Because there were quite a number of female demonstrators, the fifth demonstration was called Women Demonstration.
Because there were quite a number of female demonstrators, the fifth demonstration was called Women Demonstration.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: Because there were quite a number of female demonstrators, the fifth demonstration was called Women Demonstration.

sen.j: 女性5名が近衛篤麿貴族院 (日本)議長との面談に成功した。
sen.e: Five female demonstrators were able to meet the president of the House of Peers, Atsumaro KONOE.
Five female demonstrators were able to meet the president of the House of Peers (Japan), Atsumaro KONOE.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを除き、(Japan) を加えました。
sen.e: Five female demonstrators were able to meet the president of the House of Peers (Japan), Atsumaro KONOE.

sen.j: 第6回押出しも、養性寺を起点として行われ、農民2000名が東京に向かい、うち7名が3月6日に平田東助農商務大臣との面会に成功。
sen.e: Two thousand peasants started from Yosei-ji Temple for the sixth demonstration and of those peasants, seven persons met the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, Tosuke HIRATA.
Two thousand peasants started from Yosei-ji Temple for the sixth demonstration and of those peasants, seven persons met the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, Tosuke HIRATA.
Two thousand peasants started from Yosei-ji Temple for the sixth demonstration and of those peasants, seven persons met the Minister of Agriculture and Commerce, Tosuke HIRATA.

sen.j: 大臣は第2次鉱毒調査委員会の設置を確約させることに成功した。
sen.e: Through their talks, the Minister promised to set up the Second Mine Poison Survey Committee.
Through their talks, the Minister promised to set up the Second Mine Poison Survey Committee.
Through their talks, the Minister promised to set up the Second Mine Poison Survey Committee.

sen.j: ただし、第2次鉱毒調査委員会の設置は、既に閣議決定されていて、公布されていないだけであった。
sen.e: As a matter of fact, the government had already decided before their talks to form another Mine Poison Survey Committee and it had not been officially announced.
As a matter of fact, the government had already decided before their talks to form another Mine Poison Survey Committee and it had not been officially announced.
As a matter of fact, the government had already decided before their talks to form another Mine Poison Survey Committee and it had not been officially announced.

sen.j: 委員会は、実際に3月15日に設置された。
sen.e: On March 15 the Second Mine Survey Committee was established.
On March 15, the Second Mine Survey Committee was established.
On March 15, the Second Mine Survey Committee was established.

sen.j: 別の日に内務省に150名がなだれこんだが、内務大臣は面会を拒否した。
sen.e: On the other day 150 demonstrators intruded into the office of the Ministry of Home Affairs but the Minister of Home Affairs refused to meet them.
On the other day 150 demonstrators intruded into the office of the Ministry of Home Affairs but the Minister of Home Affairs refused to meet them.
On the other day 150 demonstrators intruded into the office of the Ministry of Home Affairs but the Minister of Home Affairs refused to meet them.

sen.j: 2審判決
sen.e: Judgment of the Appellate Court
Judgment of the Appellate Court
Judgment of the Appellate Court

sen.j: 2審判決は、1名を重禁固15日、2名を罰金とするものだった。
sen.e: The court sentenced one person to 15 days in prison and two persons to fines.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The court sentenced one person to 15 days in prison and two persons to fines.
The court sentenced one person to 15 days in prison and two persons to fines.

sen.j: それはほとんど農民側全面勝訴に近いものだった。
sen.e: It was almost like overall victory for the peasants.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It was almost like overall victory for the peasants.
It was almost like overall victory for the peasants.

sen.j: これに対し、検察側は上告。
sen.e: The prosecution appealed against the sentence.
The prosecution appealed against the sentence.
The prosecution appealed against the sentence.

sen.j: 農民らも、あくまで全員無罪をかちとるために、無罪となった47名を含む全被告が上告した。
sen.e: All forty-seven defendants including those who were found innocent also appealed acquittals of all defendants to the Supreme Court.
All forty-seven defendants including those who were found innocent also appealed acquittals of all defendants to the Supreme Court.
All forty-seven defendants including those who were found innocent also appealed acquittals of all defendants to the Supreme Court.

sen.j: 大審院では書類のみの審査が行われ、5月11日、大部分の被告を無罪とするのは不当として2審判決を破棄、差し戻しとなった。
sen.e: After documentary examination, the Supreme Court decided on May 11 to overturn the appellate court's ruling that none of the defendants were innocent and remanded the case to the lower courts.
After documentary examination, the Supreme Court decided on May 11 to overturn the appellate court's ruling that none of the defendants were innocent and remanded the case to the lower courts.
After documentary examination, the Supreme Court decided on May 11 to overturn the appellate court's ruling that none of the defendants were innocent and remanded the case to the lower courts.

sen.j: 無罪となった者のうち11名の上告は認められず、この場で無罪が確定した。
sen.e: The Supreme Court turned down an appeal from eleven persons who had been found innocent and then they were finally convicted of innocence.
The Supreme Court turned down an appeal from eleven persons who had been found innocent and then they were finally convicted of innocence.
The Supreme Court turned down an appeal from eleven persons who had been found innocent and then they were finally convicted of innocence.

sen.j: 差し戻し審は仙台控訴院で行われることになった。
sen.e: The case was transferred to the Sendai Court of Appeal.
The case was transferred to the Sendai Court of Appeal.
The case was transferred to the Sendai Court of Appeal.

sen.j: これを農民らに負担を強いるようしむけたものだと考える研究者もいるが、差し戻し審を前回と別の裁判所で行うのは当時の慣例だったという主張もある。
sen.e: Some researchers say the trial was held at a court different from the previous court, because that would put a greater burden on peasants, but other researchers say it was customary to hold trials at a different court in those days.

Some researchers say the trial was held at a court different from the previous court because that would put a greater burden on peasants, but other researchers say it was customary to hold trials at a different court in those days.
sen.cmt: コンマ、余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: Some researchers say the trial was held at a court different from the previous court because that would put a greater burden on peasants, but other researchers say it was customary to hold trials at a different court in those days.

sen.j: 仙台での判決
sen.e: Judgment by the Sendai Court of Appeal
Judgment by the Sendai Court of Appeal
Judgment by the Sendai Court of Appeal

sen.j: 11月27日、仙台控訴院での第1回公判が開かれた。
sen.e: The first public trial was held on November 27 at the Sendai Court of Appeal.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The first public trial was held on November 27 at the Sendai Court of Appeal.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペースを除きました。
sen.e: The first public trial was held on November 27 at the Sendai Court of Appeal.

sen.j: 仙台の弁護人が、突然、申立書が検事直筆でないため、控訴は無効と主張した。
sen.e: The defense suddenly proclaimed that the prosecutors' appeal was legally invalid, because the petition of appeal was not written in the prosecutors' handwriting.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The defense suddenly proclaimed that the prosecutors' appeal was legally invalid because the petition of appeal was not written in the prosecutors' handwriting.
The defense suddenly proclaimed that the prosecutors' appeal was legally invalid because the petition of appeal was not written in the prosecutors' handwriting.

sen.j: （当時の刑事訴訟法では、裁判で使われる調書類はすべて直筆の署名がないと無効になった。）
sen.e: (The Code of Criminal Procedure at that time stipulated that all documents must have autograph signatures, otherwise they were judged to be no valid.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: (The Code of Criminal Procedure at that time stipulated that all documents must have autograph signatures, otherwise they were judged to be invalid.)
(The Code of Criminal Procedure at that time stipulated that all documents must have autograph signatures, otherwise they were judged to be invalid.)

sen.j: 申立書が無効という事実は東京側弁護団や被告には知らされていなかった。
sen.e: The defense team at the Tokyo Court as well as all defendants had not been informed of the fact that the prosecutors' appeal had no legal force.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The defense team at the Tokyo Court as well as all defendants had not been informed of the fact that the prosecutors' appeal had no legal force.
The defense team at the Tokyo Court as well as all defendants had not been informed of the fact that the prosecutors' appeal had no legal force.

sen.j: 実は、検察側が前橋地方裁判所に提出した最初の起訴状そのものも代筆で、そもそも裁判は最初から無効であった。
sen.e: The case had been found null and void right from the beginning, because the first indictment submitted to the Maebashi District Court had been written by someone else and not by the prosecutors themselves.

The case had been found null and void right from the beginning because the first indictment submitted to the Maebashi District Court had been written by someone else and not by the prosecutors themselves.

The case had been found null and void right from the beginning because the first indictment submitted to the Maebashi District Court had been written by someone else and not by the prosecutors themselves.

sen.j: 仙台側弁護士は、初公判の時点でこのことにも気づいていたが、軽罪での時効が迫っていたため、あえて裁判を長引かせ、時効を狙うために1審の起訴状については言及しなかった。
sen.e: The lawyers in Sendai had been aware of that from the first public trial, but they did not mention it, because they knew it would soon reach the statute of limitations for those misdemeanors and wanted to draw out the trial.

The lawyers in Sendai had been aware of that from the first public trial, but they did not mention it because they knew it would soon reach the statute of limitations for those misdemeanors and wanted to draw out the trial.

The lawyers in Sendai had been aware of that from the first public trial, but they did not mention it because they knew it would soon reach the statute of limitations for those misdemeanors and wanted to draw out the trial.

sen.j: しかし、公判後、裁判所が署名を点検してこの事実に気付いた。
sen.e: The Court investigated the signature after this trial and found no prosecutors' autographs in the documents.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The Court investigated the signature after this trial and found no prosecutors' autographs in the documents.
The Court investigated the signature after this trial and found no prosecutors' autographs in the documents.

sen.j: そして12月25日の第2回公判で、1審の起訴状に担当検事の署名がなく、起訴無効という判決がおりた。
sen.e: Then, on December 25 at the second public trial the Court rendered a judgment that the case was invalid, because there was no autograph of the prosecutor in the first bill.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Then, on December 25 at the second public trial, the Court rendered a judgment that the case was invalid because there was no autograph of the prosecutor in the first bill.
sen.cmt: コンマを修正しました。
sen.e: Then, on December 25 at the second public trial, the Court rendered a judgment that the case was invalid because there was no autograph of the prosecutor in the first bill.

sen.j: 仙台の弁護士が、何故、起訴状の署名が代筆だと気づいたのか、遠く離れた前橋の検察官の直筆署名をどうやって手に入れたのかは不明のままである。
sen.e: It is still unknown how the lawyers in Sendai found that the bill had no autographs and how they obtained the autographs of the prosecutors in Maebashi City, which is far from Sendai.
It is still unknown how the lawyers in Sendai found that the bill had no autographs and how they obtained the autographs of the prosecutors in Maebashi City which was far from Sendai.
sen.cmt: , which is→which was としました。
sen.e: It is still unknown how the lawyers in Sendai found that the bill had no autographs and how they obtained the autographs of the prosecutors in Maebashi City which was far from Sendai.

sen.j: 一説によれば、当時、東北地方の強姦事件の公判で、被害者の調書に被害者本人の署名がないという理由で無罪になることが立て続けにあり、それ以来、仙台の弁護士は調書の署名を注意してみるようになったともいう。
sen.e: Some researchers say lawyers in Sendai City came to keep their eyes peeled for signatures in the documents, since there were many cases in Tohoku region where rapists received sentence of acquittal owing to the fact that there were no autographs of rape victims in the paper.

Some researchers say lawyers in Sendai City came to keep their eyes peeled for signatures in the documents, since there were many cases in Tohoku region where rapists received sentence of acquittal owing to the fact that there were no autographs of rape victims in the paper.

Some researchers say lawyers in Sendai City came to keep their eyes peeled for signatures in the documents, since there were many cases in Tohoku region where rapists received sentence of acquittal owing to the fact that there were no autographs of rape victims in the paper.

sen.j: なお、のちに法が改正され、被害者の調書については、直筆署名でなくてもよいことになった。
sen.e: Meanwhile, the Code of Criminal Procedure was later revised and victims no longer need to autograph in the documents.
Meanwhile, the Code of Criminal Procedure was later revised and victims no longer need to autograph in the documents.
Meanwhile, the Code of Criminal Procedure was later revised and victims no longer need to autograph in the documents.

sen.j: この時点では川俣事件の時効は完成しておらず、検察側は再び1審から起訴をやり直すこともできたが、行わなかった。
sen.e: The statute of limitation in the Kawamata Incident was not completed at this point, however the prosecution did not bring up the case, though they could have done it.
Since the statute of limitation in the Kawamata Incident was not completed at this point, the prosecution could have brought up the case but they did not.
sen.cmt: Since～として、however, though を除き文の後半部分を修正しました。
sen.e: Since the statute of limitation in the Kawamata Incident was not completed at this point, the prosecution could have brought up the case but they did not.

sen.j: 再度世論が沸騰するのを防ぐためだと考えられている。
sen.e: It is said that it was because they wanted to prevent the another rising tide of public opinion against the mining poisons.
It is said that it was because they wanted to prevent the another rising tide of public opinion.
sen.cmt: against the mining poisons を除きました。
sen.e: It is said that it was because they wanted to prevent the another rising tide of public opinion.

sen.j: ただし、第2回公判直前の12月23日に、複数の被告が再収監されていた。
sen.e: Meanwhile, several defendants were re-imprisoned on December 23, just before the second public trial.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Meanwhile, several defendants were re-imprisoned on December 23, just before the second public trial.
Meanwhile, several defendants were re-imprisoned on December 23, just before the second public trial.

sen.j: これを再起訴の準備と見る研究者もいる。
sen.e: Some researchers think this action demonstrates the intention of re-prosecuting.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Some researchers think this action demonstrates the intention of re-prosecuting.
Some researchers think this action demonstrates the intention of re-prosecuting.

sen.j: 事件の影響
sen.e: Effects of the Kawamata Incident
Effects of the Kawamata Incident
Effects of the Kawamata Incident

sen.j: 事件後鉱毒反対運動が下火になりました。
sen.e: The movement against the copper poisoning died down after the Kawamata Incident.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The movement against the copper poisoning died down after the Kawamata Incident.
The movement against the copper poisoning died down after the Kawamata Incident.

sen.j: 事件によって有力な活動家が拘束され、また、活動を行うと逮捕されるかもしれないという不安からったと考える研究者がいる。
sen.e: Some researchers say it was because leading activists were arrested at the Incident and because peasants became afraid that they might also be arrested.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Some researchers say it was because leading activists were arrested at the Incident and because peasants were afraid that they might also be arrested.
Some researchers say it was because leading activists were arrested at the Incident and because peasants were afraid that they might also be arrested.

sen.j: 田中正造も、1901年当時、同様の主張を行った。
sen.e: Shozo TANAKA also made a similar comment in 1901.
Shozo TANAKA also made a similar comment in 1901.
Shozo TANAKA also made a similar comment in 1901.

sen.j: これに対し、第5回、第6回押出しが行われており、鉱毒反対運動の弱体化は、事件や裁判とは関係ないと考える研究者もいる。
sen.e: However, some researchers say the Kawamata Incident or the trials of the Kawamata Incident had nothing to do with weakening of the opposition movement, because two demonstrations, the fifth and the sixth, were staged after the Kawamata Incident.

However, some researchers say the Kawamata Incident or the trials of the Kawamata Incident had nothing to do with weakening of the opposition movement because two demonstrations, the fifth and the sixth, were staged after that.
sen.cmt: コンマを除き、最後のthe Kawamata Incidentを省略しました。
sen.e: However, some researchers say the Kawamata Incident or the trials of the Kawamata Incident had nothing to do with weakening of the opposition movement because two demonstrations, the fifth and the sixth, were staged after that.

sen.j: この説をとる研究者の多くは、1903年秋以降、鉱毒被害地が豊作になったことで運動が弱体化したと考えている。
sen.e: Many of those researchers who supported this idea consider that the movement weakened after 1903 when the peasants in the copper poisoned area had a rich harvest.
Many of those researchers who supported this idea consider that the movement weakened when the peasants in the copper poisoned area had a rich harvest from autumn in 1903 onward.
sen.cmt: after 1903を除き、最後にfrom autumn～を加えました。
sen.e: Many of those researchers who supported this idea consider that the movement weakened when the peasants in the copper poisoned area had a rich harvest from autumn in 1903 onward.

sen.j: 第6回押出しの次の押出しが行われたのは56年後の1958年6月11日のことだった。
sen.e: On June 11, 1958, 56 years after the sixth demonstration the seventh demonstration was held.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: On June 11, 1958, 56 years after the sixth demonstration the seventh demonstration was held.
On June 11, 1958, 56 years after the sixth demonstration the seventh demonstration was held.

sen.j: 毛里田村農民らが足尾線で足尾町の古河鉱業に押出しを行った。
sen.e: The peasants living in Morita Village marched into the buildings of Furukawa Mining Co., Ltd in Ashio Town.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処、「足尾線で」とは具体的にどういうことなのか、調べましたが不明でしたので、ここでは英訳に入れませんでした。
sen.e: The peasants living in Morita Village practiced the demonstration to the Furukawa Mining Industry in Ashio Town by the Ashio Line.
sen.cmt: by the Ashio Line を加えたため、marched→practiced～に修正、Co., Ltd→Industry としました。
sen.e: The peasants living in Morita Village practiced the demonstration to the Furukawa Mining Industry in Ashio Town by the Ashio Line.

sen.j: 衆議院議員であり、農民運動の先導者であった田中正造は、1900年2月15日、事件に関する質問演説を行っている途中で、当時所属していた憲政本党を離党した。
sen.e: Shozo TANAKA, a member of the Lower House and a leader of the peasant movement, announced when he was questioning the Kawamata Incident at the Diet meeting on February 15, 1900 his departure from the Kenseihon Party with which he was then affiliated.

Shozo TANAKA, a member of the House of Representatives and a leader of the peasant movement, announced his departure from the Kenseihon Party which he was then affiliated when he was questioning the Kawamata Incident at the Diet meeting on February 15, 1900.
sen.cmt: Lower House→House of Representatives, with which→which, when～の位置を最後に修正しました。
sen.e: Shozo TANAKA, a member of the House of Representatives and a leader of the peasant movement, announced his departure from the Kenseihon Party which he was then affiliated when he was questioning the Kawamata Incident at the Diet meeting on February 15, 1900.

sen.j: その後
sen.e: Event After the Kawamata Incident
Event After the Kawamata Incident
Event After the Kawamata Incident

sen.j: 事件発生百年後の2000年2月13日、群馬県邑楽郡明和町の事件発生現場に、川俣事件記念碑が建てられた。
sen.e: Hundred years after the Kawamata Incident the monument of the Kawamata Incident was set up at the incident site in Meiwa Town, Oura-gun, Gunma Prefecture on February 13, 2000.
Hundred years after the event, the monument of the Kawamata Incident was set up at the scene of the incident in Meiwa Town, Oura County, Gunma Prefecture on February 13, 2000.
